title: Ecosystems: Components and Relationships
introduction: An ecosystem is a community of living organisms (biotic factors) interacting with their physical (abiotic) environment. It can be as large as a forest or as small as a pond. Understanding ecosystems helps us see how all parts of nature are connected.

items.title: Biotic (Living) Components
items.content:
These are all the living or once-living parts of an ecosystem. They include:
  • Producers: Plants that make their own food (e.g., trees, algae).
  • Consumers: Animals that eat other organisms.
  • Decomposers: Organisms like bacteria and fungi that break down dead matter.

items.title: Abiotic (Non-Living) Components
items.content:
These are the non-living physical and chemical parts of the environment. They include:
  • Sunlight
  • Water
  • Soil and minerals
  • Temperature
  • Air (gases like Oxygen and Carbon Dioxide)

sections.title: Relationships in an Ecosystem
sections.content:
Organisms in an ecosystem interact in many ways:

- **Predation:** One organism (the predator) hunts and kills another (the prey). Example: A lion hunting a zebra.

- **Competition:** Organisms struggle for the same limited resources like food, water, or territory.

- **Symbiosis:** A close, long-term interaction between two different species. This includes:
  - **Mutualism:** Both species benefit (e.g., bees pollinating flowers).
  - **Parasitism:** One benefits (parasite) and the other is harmed (host) (e.g., a tick on a dog).
  - **Commensalism:** One benefits, and the other is unaffected (e.g., a bird nesting in a tree).

questions.question: WASSCE 2018: (a) What is an ecosystem? (b) Differentiate between biotic and abiotic components, giving two examples of each.
questions.gradingRubric: (a) Definition (2 marks). (b) Differentiation (2 marks), 2 examples for biotic (1 mark), 2 examples for abiotic (1 mark).
questions.modelAnswer:
(a) An ecosystem is a biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment. 
(b) Biotic components are the living parts of an ecosystem, such as plants and animals. Abiotic components are the non-living parts, such as water and sunlight.

questions.question: WASSCE 2021: Explain the term 'mutualism' with a relevant example.
questions.gradingRubric: Definition of mutualism (2 marks), correct example (2 marks).
questions.modelAnswer: Mutualism is a type of symbiotic relationship where both species involved benefit from the interaction. A classic example is the relationship between bees and flowers; the bee gets nectar (food), and in the process, it pollinates the flower, helping it to reproduce.
